data.name: Beef Wellington
data.introduction: A dish that's fallen out of favour and then become popular again more times than we can count, beef Wellington's origins are as unclear as its connection to Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington. Traditionally, it's a beef fillet steak, coated in pâté and mushroom duxelles (an extremely finely chopped mixture of mushrooms, shallots and herbs), wrapped in puff pastry, then baked. Its modern-day popularity is largely thanks to Gordon Ramsay who's made it one of his signature dishes.
ingredients: 1.5 kg beef fillet, trimmed and tied
recipe: Season the beef with black pepper. Heat the oil in a large frying pan, add the beef, and cook over a high heat until browned all over.

Put the beef fillet in a roasting tin and cook in a preheated oven at 220°C/425°F/gas mark 7 for 25 minutes for rare beef, 35 minutes for medium, or 40 minutes for well-done. Leave to cool completely.

Meanwhile, melt the butter in the frying pan, add the onion and mushrooms, and cook, stirring, for 3 minutes or until softened. Increase the heat to high, and cook until the excess moisture has evaporated. Turn into a bowl and leave to cool completely.
Add the liver pâté to the mushroom and onion mixture, season with salt and pepper, and stir well to combine.

data.name: Peking duck
data.introduction: A dish cooked and eaten in Beijing since the Imperial era, today Peking duck is a Chinese restaurant favourite across the world. There are countless methods of preparing and cooking the duck, but originally it was roasted in a closed oven until the kitchens of the Qing Dynasty developed the open-oven style to cook several ducks at the same time. The duck is then served with steamed Chinese pancakes, cucumber, spring onion and sweet bean sauce.
recipe: Preheat your oven to 180°C/356°F/gas mark 4 and remove the duck legs from the fridge about 20 mins before you want to cook them.
Prick the skin of the duck legs all over with a fork or skewer.
In a bowl, mix together your five spice, garlic and salt, then rub over the duck legs.
Place the duck legs in an ovenproof dish and cook for about 60 mins. Leave them in a little longer if they haven’t crisped up enough.
While the duck is cooking, prepare your cucumber and spring onions.
Once the duck is cooked, leave it to rest for about 10 mins then shred the meat using two forks or your fingers.
Serve the shredded duck with the hoisin sauce, pancakes, cucumber and spring onions on the side.

data.name: Shakshuka
data.introduction: Claimed as one of their own throughout North Africa and the Middle East, untangling the web of where shakshuka is from is simply impossible. All we know is that it's an incredibly tasty and filling dish that's become a popular breakfast and brunch meal throughout the world. Literally translating as a mixture, it's usually cooked by reducing down tomatoes, onions and a range of spices before the eggs are poached on top.
ingredients: 8 large tomatoes on the vine, chopped
recipe: Preheat the oven to 220°C/425°F/gas mark 7.

Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a large frying pan. Season the aubergine slices and fry them in batches for 3–4 minutes on each side, until golden and tender, adding more oil as necessary. Transfer the slices to a plate as they are cooked.

Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a medium frying pan and sauté the onion gently over a low to medium heat for about 8 minutes, stirring every now and then, until softened. Stir in the garlic and cook for a further minute.
Tip the tomatoes into the pan along with any juice and stir into the onion. Cook for 8 minutes until the tomatoes have broken down and softened – they should be a pulp.
Pour in the tomato juice and cook, again over a low heat, for 5 minutes. The sauce will be quite thick by this stage.
Season with salt, black pepper and the cumin, if using.
Spread a layer of aubergine slices over a large, ovenproof dish, then spoon over half the tomato sauce. Repeat to make two layers.
Make a hole in the sauce with the back of a large spoon and crack an egg into it. Do the same all round the dish until you’ve positioned all the eggs. Scatter over the feta.
Bake in the oven for 5 minutes. Pick the leaves off the parsley and mint sprigs, and chop roughly. When the shakshuka is ready, scatter over the herbs and serve with the warm pitta bread.

data.name: Laksa
data.introduction: A spicy, sweet, sour and fragrant soup from Southeast Asia, laksa is mostly associated with Malaysia. The origins are murky with several theories in different countries and a wide range of laksa exist, from regional varieties to differences in preparation. Typically, either a rich and spicy coconut milk broth or a sour asam broth made with tamarind, the soup is made with thick wheat noodles or rice vermicelli and served with chicken, prawn or fish.
ingredients: 1 red chilli, deseeded and finely sliced
1 tbsp roughly chopped coriander (cilantro), plus leaves to garnish
1 pinch each of sea salt and freshly ground black pepper
recipe: Place a saucepan over a medium heat and add the olive oil.
Stir in the chilli and cook for a minute, then add the Thai red curry paste and cook for a further minute.
Whisk in the hot vegetable stock and coconut milk and bring to the boil. Stir in the fish sauce, toss in the noodles and cook for 2 minutes.
Squeeze in the lime juice, add the raw prawns and cook for about 4 minutes.
Stir in the chopped coriander and season with salt and pepper.
Serve in bowls with the coriander leaves and the lime wedges on top for squeezing over.

data.name: Clam chowder
data.introduction: Creamy clam chowder is Massachusetts' finest dish that's prevalent throughout New England. Made with potatoes, crushed oyster crackers and chunks of local clam, it’s a flavourful and hearty dish to have all year long. The most famous place to eat it, Legal Sea Foods in Boston, began life as a market frequented by Julia Child and has been cooking up perfect chowder for decades.
ingredients: 4 slices thick-cut bacon, cut into lardons
24 clams, shucked, with their liquor, cut into pieces if large
1 tbsp fresh parsley or chives, minced
recipe: In a heavy-bottomed pot, cook the bacon over medium high heat, stirring frequently, until browned and crisp, about 5 minutes. Drain the bacon on paper towels.
Add the onion to the bacon drippings and cook, stirring, until the onion has softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the flour. Add the potatoes and stock.
Cook, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are tender, about 15 minutes.
Add the cream and bring to a simmer.
Add the clams and reserved bacon and simmer for another few minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Serve garnished with parsley or chives.

data.name: Ramen
data.introduction: A Japanese noodle soup, ramen has grown in popularity outside of Japan in the last decade and it's easy to see why. In its simple form, it's a rich meat (or occasionally fish) broth, flavoured with soy or miso and served with toppings such as mushrooms, seaweed, sesame seeds, spring onions and soft-boiled egg. As with most dishes, there are regional varieties too, including the most popular tonkotsu (pork bone broth) ramen of Kyushu and the miso ramen of Hokkaido.
ingredients: 150 g packet miso ramen noodles (or plain noodles)
1 handful frozen peas, or any vegetables you have lurking in the fridge (carrots, sugarsnap peas, corn, bean sprouts, finely shredded cabbage, courgette etc)
1 tbsp red or brown miso paste (if using plain noodles)
1 spring onion, sliced and placed in a bowl of iced water for a few minutes
1 pinch black or white sesame seeds
1 tsp toasted sesame oil, to taste
1 handful Japanese dried nori seaweed, to serve (optional)
recipe: Cook the ramen noodles according to the packet instructions, adding the frozen peas (or whichever vegetables you opt for) to the pan so they cook at the same time.
Cook the egg by poaching it in the broth (whisk it in a bowl first then pour it into the broth or crack it in), boiling it whole in a separate pan, or giving it a quick fry.
Add the miso paste to the noodle cooking liquid (if cooking plain noodles) and stir through.
Remove from the heat and garnish with the chilli, drained spring onion, sesame seeds, sesame oil and any other toppings you like.
The egg goes on last if you cooked it separately, along with the seaweed (if using).

data.name: Cacio e pepe
data.introduction: There are countless divine Italian pasta recipes, but this one is genius in its simplicity. Translating as cheese and pepper, the dish, as its name suggests, uses a handful of basic ingredients: black pepper, cheese, pasta and butter. You'll find versions made with either spaghetti, linguine or pici, which is a short, thick worm-like pasta, and there's also debate about what cheese to use – it's usually either Parmesan or pecorino romano.
ingredients: 1 pinch sea salt, for the cooking water
1 tsp freshly ground black pepper, plus extra to serve
60 g Parmesan or pecorino or a mixture (or a vegetarian alternative), finely grated, plus extra to serve
recipe: Cook the pasta in a saucepan of boiling, salted water for 6–8 minutes, or until it is not quite tender and still has some bite remaining. Drain and reserve the pasta water.
Quickly return the pan to a medium-high heat. Add the butter and, when melted, add the pepper and heat for about 1 minute until fragrant.
Add a ladleful of pasta cooking water (about 100 ml/3.5 fl oz/scant 0.5 cup) to the pan and bring to the boil.
Reduce the heat, return the pasta to the pan with three-quarters of the cheese, then stir and shake the pan to melt the cheese and create a sauce that clings to the pasta.
Add the remaining cheese and toss the pasta until it melts and you have a silky smooth sauce, adding a splash more of the cooking water if the sauce seems dry.
Divide between warmed dishes and serve immediately with extra cheese and pepper.

data.name: Boeuf bourguignon
data.introduction: This classic French dish might look rustic, but plenty of work and skill goes into making it just right. Consisting of beef slowly braised in red wine, plus beef stock, carrots, onions and sometimes mushrooms, this super-rich dish is packed with layers of flavour. It's also become one of the most famous recipes from Julia Child's groundbreaking cookbook The French Chef.
ingredients: 800 g Beef brisket, cut into large cubes
4 Garlic cloves, crushed with the flat edge of a knife or your hand
600 ml Veal stock or chicken stock
2 Carrots, peeled, halved lengthways and cut into chunks
1 Bouquet garni (made with 1 parsley sprig, 1 thyme sprig and 1 small bay leaf)
recipe: In a deep dish, mix together the beef, wine, thyme, garlic and Cognac. Cover with cling film and leave to marinate in the fridge for at least 3 hours.
Drain the meat into a bowl, using a colander, and reserve the marinade.

Heat 4 tablespoons of the oil in a large saucepan or cast iron pot over a medium hear. Add the meat and cook for 20 minutes until brown, season with salt and pepper, then sprinkle with the flour and cook, stirring, for a further 2-3 minutes.

Add the stock and reserved marinade and bring to the boil. Skim the foam off the surface and add the bouquet garni, then reduce the heat to low and simmer, partially covered, for 1 hour 45 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the meat is tender. By that time you should have a rich, silky sauce.

About 50 minutes before the end of the cooking time, heat another medium saucepan with 1 tablespoon of the oil over a medium-low heat. Add the carrots and onions and cook for 10 minutes or until soft and pale gold in colour, then add to the meat saucepan.

When the beef is almost ready, heat the remaining oil in a frying pan over a medium heat. Add the mushrooms and pancetta and fry 8-10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until golden brown, then add them to the beef. Check the seasoning adjusting the salt and pepper, if necessary, throw in the parsley and stir gently without breaking the delicate pieces of beef.
Serve with hot creamed mash potatoes for a perfect winter warmer.

data.name: Pho
data.introduction: This warm, comforting noodle dish has taken the world by storm and rightly so. Its apparent simplicity hides complex flavours that are at once unctuous and refreshing. Born in northern Vietnam in the late 19th century, pho’s development was influenced by Chinese and French cooking, mirroring the history of the country. Today, it is a uniquely Vietnamese offering that you won’t have to go far to find, wherever you are in the world.
ingredients: 250 g flat pho noodles, cooked per packet instructions
recipe: Heat a dry frying pan and toast the spices quickly till they become aromatic. Remove and keep on the side.
Slice on onion in half and char it flat side down in a hot, dry pan until black. Remove, and add the ginger until coloured on both sides.
Debone the short ribs, browning the bone in a dry pan on every side.
Add the bone to the crockpot with stock, water, onion, the garlic clove, spices, ginger, coriander stalks and shiitake mushrooms.
Slice the short rib lengthways in thin slices and add to the pot.
For best results, set your Crock-Pot or slow cooker to low (for 4–6 hours' cooking). You could also use high (for 2–3 hours' cooking).
Cook until the beef gets soft to the bite but doesn’t break up.
Add fish sauce and salt to taste.
Remove the bones, spices, ginger, garlic and lemongrass, then portion into bowls with the prepared noodles.
Slice the spring onion and chilli, add to the pho and top with lightly torn coriander leaves and mint. Serve with lime wedges.

data.name: Southern fried chicken
data.introduction: You might think that there couldn't be anything easier than deep-frying a piece of chicken – but you'd be wrong to assume it's as simple as that. Making the perfect batter, adding just the right amount of seasoning and choosing the best way to fry takes practise. A dish deeply rooted in the American South, a perfect basket of fried chicken is one for the bucket list.
ingredients: 1 pinch sea salt, for the cooking water
1 tsp freshly ground black pepper, plus extra to serve
60 g Parmesan or pecorino or a mixture (or a vegetarian alternative), finely grated, plus extra to serve
recipe: Cook the pasta in a saucepan of boiling, salted water for 6–8 minutes, or until it is not quite tender and still has some bite remaining. Drain and reserve the pasta water.
Quickly return the pan to a medium-high heat. Add the butter and, when melted, add the pepper and heat for about 1 minute until fragrant.
Add a ladleful of pasta cooking water (about 100 ml/3.5 fl oz/scant 0.5 cup) to the pan and bring to the boil.
Reduce the heat, return the pasta to the pan with three-quarters of the cheese, then stir and shake the pan to melt the cheese and create a sauce that clings to the pasta.
Add the remaining cheese and toss the pasta until it melts and you have a silky smooth sauce, adding a splash more of the cooking water if the sauce seems dry.
Divide between warmed dishes and serve immediately with extra cheese and pepper.

data.name: Poutine
data.introduction: It might not be a looker, but this Québec dish is certainly delicious, and is now not only popular across Canada and the northeast of the US but further afield too. Comprising fluffy-on-the-inside, crunchy-on-the-outside French fries, and thick, rich and meaty gravy, poutine is elevated to a culinary event by the addition of cheese curds. These small, solidified white cheese bites retain some of their shape under the heat of the gravy.
ingredients: 500 g large white potatoes (such as Maris Piper)
200 g cheese curds, or buffalo mozzarella
400 ml gravy, beef or onion, either shop-bought or homemade
recipe: Bring a large pot of salted water to the boil and pre-heat the oven to 220°C/430°F/gas mark 7.
Keeping the skin on, slice the potatoes lengthways into 1cm (0.5in) slices then cut into sticks (chips).
Cook the chips in the boiling water for 5 minutes then drain.
Line a large baking tray with parchment paper and spray with a little light oil spray.

Place the chips onto the baking tray in a single layer, season and spray all over with the light oil. Cook in the pre-heated oven for 25 minutes giving them a shake halfway through or until golden and crispy.
Make sure the gravy is at boiling temperature or piping hot.
Transfer the chips to a serving dish, break the cheese curds (or mozzarella) into small chunks, place them on the chips and pour over the hot gravy.

data.name: Biryani
data.introduction: A celebration of spices and rice, biryani's origins lie with the Muslims of the Indian subcontinent. Today, endless varieties of biryani exist, depending on the region where it's cooked and the cook who makes it, but the basics – rice and an assortment of spices – remain untouchable. You can make yours with meat or skip it for a vegan or vegetarian treat.
ingredients: 5 cm (2in) piece of cinnamon stick, broken in half
5 cm (2in) piece of fresh root ginger, grated
6 skinless, boneless chicken thighs, cut into bite-size pieces
1 pinch each of fine sea salt and freshly ground black pepper
4 dollops of natural yogurt, to serve (optional)
recipe: Soak the rice in a large bowl of warm water for 15 minutes, then drain and rinse under cold running water until the water runs clear. Put the kettle on to boil.

Meanwhile, heat the butter and oil in a deep frying pan (skillet) or a flameproof casserole dish (Dutch oven) set over a medium heat. Fry the onion, chilli, cardamom pods and cinnamon stick for 5 minutes, stirring frequently.
Meanwhile, in a large bowl, mix the grated ginger and garlic with the dried spices, ½ teaspoon salt and a generous grinding of black pepper. Add the chicken and massage the spice mix into the meat.
Add the chicken to the pan and fry for 5 minutes until the chicken has changed colour and the spices are fragrant.
Stir in half of the crispy fried onions and season really well.

Scatter the rice over the chicken in an even layer, then pour over the boiling water and add ½ teaspoon salt. The rice should be just submerged under the water. Agitate the rice with a spoon but don’t stir.
Bring to the boil and cook for 6 minutes. Cover with foil and a tight-fitting lid to seal in the steam, then turn off the heat and leave to stand, undisturbed, for 10 minutes.
Remove the lid and foil and sprinkle with the remaining fried onions, coriander leaves and flaked almonds. Serve immediately with yogurt on the side if you like.

data.name: Tacos
data.introduction: These soft corn tortillas full of delicious beef, pork and chicken have mysterious origins that are often traced back to Mexico's 18th-century silver mines. Contrary to American tacos, the Mexican version doesn't include garnishes like lettuce, tomato, cheese or even sour cream. In fact, Mexican tacos are usually topped with coriander, finely diced white onion and a type of salsa or, sometimes, guacamole.
ingredients: 500 g king prawns, peeled and deveined
recipe: Set a large frying pan over a high heat. Once the pan is hot, add the oil, shallot and celery. Fry for a minute until everything starts to sizzle, then reduce the heat to medium. Fry, stirring occasionally, for about 10 minutes, until the shallot is just softened. If the shallot starts to catch, reduce the heat further.

When the shallot is soft, increase the heat to high and add the garlic and celery salt. Fry for a minute then throw in the vodka or white wine and allow the alcohol to bubble and evaporate almost entirely.

Add the Tabasco, horseradish, Worcestershire sauce and tomato juice and bring to the boil, then throw in the prawns. Fry just until the prawns are cooked through, then remove from the heat and stir in the parsley and a good grinding of black pepper.
For the celeriac slaw, coarsely grate the celeriac into a mixing bowl. Add the lime juice, celery salt and coriander.
To serve, fill the tortillas with the slaw before layering with the prawns. Top with a squeeze of mayonnaise and serve with lime wedges and extra slaw.

data.name: Som tam
data.introduction: This spicy, crunchy salad is the taste of Southeast Asia on a plate, made with shredded unripe green papaya and other local fruit and vegetables tossed in a delicious sweet and sour dressing of palm sugar, chilli peppers and lime juice. Originating from Laos, it’s also eaten throughout Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand. Making a traditional som tam means lots of shredding and pounding with a pestle and mortar, but modern, less messy and time-consuming takes on the traditional dish abound.
ingredients: 1 large or 2 smaller mangoes (opt for firmer ones, so not too ripe)
1 red chilli, deseeded and sliced lengthways
recipe: Roughly chop the fish and place it in a food-processor with the curry paste. Pulse until you have a coarse paste - don't whip it up too finely.

If you don't have a food-processor, just lay the fish and curry paste on a large cutting board and chop with a big knife, pressing with the side of the knife to mash and mix the fish with the curry paste.

Fold in the breadcrumbs and shape into balls. Dust with a little flour to keep them from sticking. You should be able to get eight little fish cakes out of the mixture, giving you two for each person. Pop them into the fridge to firm up for 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, make the salad. Using a vegetable peeler, peel the courgettes along their length, then just keep going, making strips of the flesh until you reach the seed pod in the centre. Nibble the seed pod while you cook or thinly slice it and add it to the salad. Peel the carrot in the same way.

Peel one side of the mango using a vegetable peeler and then shave off long, thin slivers of the mango's flesh with the peeler, so it's similar in shape and texture to the courgettes and carrots. Continue around the whole of the mango until you've used most of it up. Save any remaining bits of mango for a fruit salad.
Mix the courgettes, carrot and mango together with the garlic, chilli, salt, lime juice and zest, and sugar or honey. Set aside while you fry the fishcakes.
Press each ball down into a little cake and fry in olive oil until golden on each side. Serve with the som tam salad and garnish with coriander leaves and crushed peanuts.

data.name: Falafel
data.introduction: This round, deep-fried patty of ground chickpeas, herbs, spices and onions makes for a tasty veggie treat. Falafel has a thousand-year history, probably hailing from Egypt, where it was eaten as a substitute for meat by Coptic Christians during Lent and was made with fava beans. The dish later migrated towards the Levant, where it took on its current chickpea form.
ingredients: 400 g chickpeas, soaked overnight in cold water and drained
recipe: Blitz the onion and garlic in a food-processer until fine. Add the herbs and continue to blend until they are completely whizzed up. Add the chickpeas, gram flour, cumin, coriander, Aleppo pepper flakes, baking powder and bicarbonate of soda.
Season with a really good pinch of salt and blitz again for a few minutes to combine.
Scrape the sides down with a spatula and blend until the mixture combines into a paste. Roll into 30–32 small falafel the size of walnuts.
Heat the vegetable oil in a deep saucepan over a medium–high heat. You will need about 7–10cm (3 inches) oil, enough to completely cover your falafel.

Cook the falafel, a few at a time, for 1–2 minutes until golden. You have to watch the heat, adjusting it so that they don’t cook too fast and burn. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on kitchen paper.
Serve in the pitta with lettuce, parsley, pickles, a sprinkle of sumac, a drizzle of tahini and chilli sauce to taste.

data.name: Butter Chicken (Murgh Makhani)
data.introduction: One of India's most loved exports, Butter Chicken was accidentally birthed in the 1950s at the Moti Mahal restaurant in Delhi. By mixing leftover tandoori chicken with a rich, buttery tomato gravy, a legend was born. It is known for its mild, creamy texture and aromatic spice profile.
recipe: Marinate chicken in yogurt, lemon juice, ginger-garlic paste, and spices for at least 3 hours.
Pan-fry or grill the chicken pieces until charred and cooked through; set aside.
In a large pan, melt butter and add tomato puree. Simmer for 15 minutes until thickened.
Stir in the cream, cooked chicken, and kasuri methi. Simmer for another 5 minutes.
Serve hot with garlic naan or basmati rice.

data.name: Paella Valenciana
data.introduction: The pride of Valencia, Spain. While many variations exist today (including seafood), the traditional Valenciana version usually features rabbit, chicken, and snails. The key to a perfect paella is the 'socarrat'—the delicious toasted crust of rice at the bottom of the pan.
recipe: Heat oil in a paella pan and brown the chicken until golden.
Add green beans and grated tomato; cook until the tomato liquid evaporates.
Stir in the paprika and rice, coating the grains in oil for 1 minute.
Pour in the hot stock mixed with saffron. Do not stir the rice again.
Simmer on medium-low until the liquid is absorbed and a crust forms at the bottom. Rest for 5 minutes before serving.

data.name: Coq au Vin
data.introduction: A cornerstone of French bistro cooking. This dish involves braising chicken with wine, lardons (bacon), mushrooms, and garlic. Traditionally made with an older rooster (coq) to tenderize the tough meat, modern recipes use standard chicken for a silky, rich result.
recipe: Fry the pancetta until crisp, then remove. In the same fat, brown the chicken pieces and remove.
Sauté onions and mushrooms until browned.
Return chicken and bacon to the pot. Stir in tomato paste and garlic.
Pour in the wine and herbs. Cover and simmer for 45-50 minutes until chicken is tender.
Thicken the sauce with a butter-flour paste (beurre manié) if desired and serve.

data.name: Pad Thai
data.introduction: The ultimate Thai street food. Developed in the 1930s to promote national identity, it has since become a global favorite. It perfectly balances the four pillars of Thai flavor: salty (fish sauce), sour (tamarind), sweet (palm sugar), and spicy (chilli).
ingredients: Handful of bean sprouts and crushed peanuts
recipe: Whisk tamarind, fish sauce, and sugar in a small bowl to make the sauce.
Heat oil in a wok and fry tofu and prawns until cooked.
Push ingredients to the side, scramble the eggs in the center.
Add noodles and sauce. Toss vigorously over high heat until noodles are soft.
Fold in bean sprouts and serve with peanuts and lime wedges.

data.name: Moussaka
data.introduction: The definitive Greek comfort food. While versions exist across the Levant, the Greek version—layered with eggplant, spiced meat, and a thick topping of Béchamel sauce—was popularized by chef Nicholas Tselementes in the 1920s.
recipe: Salt the eggplant slices, let sit for 20 mins, rinse, and fry in olive oil until golden.
Sauté onion and meat until browned. Add tomatoes and cinnamon; simmer for 20 mins.
Layer eggplant and meat sauce in a baking dish, finishing with a layer of eggplant.
Pour Béchamel sauce over the top and sprinkle with cheese.
Bake at 180°C for 45 minutes until the top is golden brown.

data.name: Wiener Schnitzel
data.introduction: A national dish of Austria, the Wiener Schnitzel is a thin, breaded, and pan-fried veal cutlet. Its history is a matter of pride in Vienna, where law dictates it must be made of veal to bear the name. It is famously larger than the plate it is served on and traditionally accompanied by a lemon wedge and potato salad.
ingredients: 100g clarified butter or lard for frying
recipe: Place the cutlets between sheets of plastic wrap and pound with a meat mallet until 4mm thin.
Season the meat with salt and pepper. Set up three bowls: flour, beaten eggs, and breadcrumbs.
Coat each cutlet in flour, then egg, and finally breadcrumbs, pressing lightly to adhere.
Heat the butter in a large pan. Fry the schnitzel for 2–3 minutes per side until golden brown, basting with hot butter.
Drain on paper towels and serve immediately with lemon.

data.name: Tom Yum Goong
data.introduction: The quintessential Thai soup. This 'hot and sour' masterpiece is characterized by its distinct aromatic herbs: lemongrass, galangal, and kaffir lime leaves. It is a refreshing yet fiery dish that showcases the complexity of Thai coastal flavors.
ingredients: 2 tbsp roasted chili paste (Nam Prik Pao)
recipe: Bring the stock to a boil. Add lemongrass, galangal, and lime leaves; simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the mushrooms and prawns. Cook until prawns turn pink and are just cooked through.
Stir in the chili paste and fish sauce. Turn off the heat.
Add the lime juice last (to keep the flavor bright) and garnish with fresh cilantro and bird's eye chilies.

data.name: Osso Buco alla Milanese
data.introduction: A specialty of Lombardy, Italy. This dish consists of cross-cut veal shanks braised with vegetables, white wine, and broth. It is traditionally topped with gremolata (a mix of lemon zest, garlic, and parsley) and served with Saffron Risotto.
ingredients: 1 onion, 1 carrot, 1 celery stick, finely diced
For gremolata: 1 lemon (zested), 1 garlic clove (minced), handful of parsley
recipe: Dust veal shanks in flour and sear in a heavy pot until browned. Remove and set aside.
Sauté the onion, carrot, and celery in the same pot until softened.
Add tomato paste and wine, scraping the bottom of the pan to deglaze.
Return the meat to the pot, add stock, cover, and simmer on low for 2 hours or until meat is falling off the bone.
Mix gremolata ingredients and sprinkle over the meat just before serving.

data.name: Chicken Tikka Masala
data.introduction: While its roots are Indian, this dish is famously claimed as a British national dish. It features roasted marinated chicken chunks (tikka) in a spiced, creamy, orange-colored sauce. It is the perfect 'gateway' curry for those new to Indian spices.
ingredients: 2 tsp turmeric, 2 tsp cumin, 2 tsp paprika
recipe: Marinate chicken in yogurt and half the spices for at least 1 hour. Grill or pan-fry until charred.
Fry onion in a pan, add the remaining spices and ginger-garlic paste. Cook for 2 minutes.
Add tomatoes and simmer until the sauce thickens and oil begins to separate.
Stir in the cream and the cooked chicken. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Garnish with cilantro and serve with pilau rice.

data.name: Sushi (Nigiri & Maki)
data.introduction: Japan's most iconic culinary export. Sushi is as much an art form as it is a meal, focusing on the quality of the vinegared rice and the freshness of the seafood. Whether it's a simple slice of fish on rice (Nigiri) or rolled in seaweed (Maki), balance is key.
ingredients: 2 tbsp rice vinegar, 1 tbsp sugar, 1 tsp salt
recipe: Wash rice until water runs clear. Cook and then fold in the vinegar, sugar, and salt mixture while cooling.
For Nigiri: Wet hands, form small oval mounds of rice, and place a thin slice of raw fish on top.
For Maki: Place nori on a bamboo mat, spread rice, add fish/vegetable strips, and roll tightly.
Slice rolls into bite-sized pieces using a very sharp, wet knife.
Serve with wasabi, ginger, and soy sauce.

data.name: Feijoada
data.introduction: The soul of Brazilian cuisine. Feijoada is a hearty black bean stew brewed with various cuts of pork and beef. Traditionally eaten on Saturdays, it's a social meal designed to be enjoyed slowly with orange slices, rice, and toasted cassava flour (farofa).
recipe: Drain the soaked beans and place in a large pot with fresh water. Bring to a boil.
Add the salted and smoked meats to the pot. Simmer on low heat for 2.5 hours.
In a separate pan, sauté onion and garlic, then add a ladle of beans and mash them to create a paste; return this paste to the main pot to thicken the stew.
Simmer for another 30 minutes until the beans are creamy.
Serve with white rice, kale, and orange slices to help digestion.

data.name: Gulyás (Hungarian Goulash)
data.introduction: A symbol of Hungary. Goulash is a soup or stew of meat and vegetables, seasoned heavily with paprika. Originating from 9th-century shepherds, the key to an authentic 'Gulyás' is using high-quality Hungarian sweet paprika and slow-cooking the beef until tender.
recipe: Cook onions in lard until translucent. Remove from heat and stir in the paprika (don't burn it!).
Add the beef cubes and caraway seeds. Cook until the meat releases its juices.
Add the chopped tomato and pepper. Cover and simmer in its own juice for 45 minutes.
Add water or stock along with carrots, parsnips, and potatoes. Cook until all vegetables are tender.
Serve hot with crusty bread or small noodles (csipetke).

data.name: Nasi Goreng
data.introduction: Indonesian fried rice, distinguished by its smoky, aromatic flavor and the use of 'Kecap Manis' (sweet soy sauce). Often described as the national dish of Indonesia, it is commonly topped with a fried egg and served with prawn crackers.
ingredients: 2 cups cooked jasmine rice (day-old is best)
recipe: Heat oil in a wok. Fry shallots, garlic, and chili until fragrant.
Add shrimp paste and chicken/prawns. Stir-fry until cooked.
Add the rice, breaking up any clumps. Pour in the Kecap Manis and stir constantly over high heat.
Push rice aside and scramble one egg into the mix.
Serve topped with a sunny-side-up egg, cucumber slices, and prawn crackers (Krupuk).

data.name: Chiles en Nogada
data.introduction: A patriotic Mexican dish representing the colors of the flag. It features Poblano chilies stuffed with 'picadillo' (a mixture of meat, fruits, and spices), topped with a walnut-based cream sauce (nogada) and pomegranate seeds. It is traditionally served in late summer.
ingredients: 4 large Poblano chilies, roasted and peeled
For sauce: 200g walnuts, 200ml crema, 100g goat cheese
Pomegranate seeds and parsley for garnish
recipe: Cook the meat with onions and garlic. Stir in the diced fruits, raisins, and almonds. Simmer until the fruits are soft.
Slit the Poblano chilies and remove seeds. Stuff them with the meat-fruit mixture.
Blend walnuts, crema, goat cheese, and a pinch of sugar until smooth to make the Nogada sauce.
Place stuffed chilies on a plate and cover generously with the cold walnut sauce.
Garnish with pomegranate seeds (red) and parsley (green) over the white sauce.

data.name: Ratatouille
data.introduction: A classic Provencal vegetable stew from Nice. Originally a meal for poor farmers, it has become a celebrated dish of French cuisine. It highlights the beauty of summer vegetables like zucchini, eggplant, and peppers, cooked until they meld into a rich, savory medley.
recipe: In a large pan, sauté the onions and garlic in olive oil until soft.
Add the peppers and eggplant; cook for 10 minutes until they start to soften.
Stir in the zucchinis and tomatoes. Season with herbs, salt, and pepper.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 30–40 minutes, allowing the vegetables to release their juices and soften completely.
Serve hot, cold, or as a side dish with crusty bread.

data.name: Jollof Rice
data.introduction: A beloved West African staple that is the subject of much friendly rivalry between nations. This 'one-pot' rice dish is cooked in a flavorful reduction of tomatoes, onions, and peppers, seasoned with thyme and scotch bonnet chilies. It is often served with fried plantains and grilled chicken.
ingredients: 3 large tomatoes and 2 red bell peppers (blended)
1 tsp curry powder and 1 tsp dried thyme
recipe: Heat oil and fry the onions until golden. Add tomato paste and fry for 5 minutes.
Add the blended tomato/pepper mix and spices. Cook until the water evaporates and the sauce thickens.
Wash the rice and add it to the pot, stirring to coat every grain in the sauce.
Pour in the stock, cover tightly with foil and a lid. Simmer on low heat for 30 minutes.
Once the rice is tender and has absorbed the flavors, fluff with a fork and serve.

data.name: Kottu Roti
data.introduction: The ultimate Sri Lankan street food. It is made by rhythmically chopping 'godamba' roti bread on a heated metal griddle, mixed with vegetables, eggs, spices, and often a spicy meat curry. The rhythmic clanging of the metal blades is a signature sound of Sri Lankan nights.
ingredients: 4 large plain rotis, shredded into strips
recipe: Heat oil in a large flat pan or wok. Sauté curry leaves, onion, and chilies.
Add vegetables and cook until slightly softened. Stir in the eggs and scramble quickly.
Add the shredded roti and the chicken curry.
Using two metal spatulas (or a large knife on a board), chop the mixture vigorously while stir-frying.
Serve hot with a side of extra gravy.

data.name: Swedish Meatballs (Köttbullar)
data.introduction: Made famous worldwide by IKEA, but a deep-seated tradition in Swedish homes. Unlike Italian meatballs, these are smaller and flavored with allspice and nutmeg. They are classically served with a creamy gravy, boiled potatoes, and tart lingonberry jam.
ingredients: For gravy: 40g butter, 40g flour, 300ml beef stock, 100ml heavy cream
recipe: Soak breadcrumbs in milk for 5 minutes. Mix with meat, spices, egg, and salt.
Roll into small, walnut-sized balls.
Fry the meatballs in butter until browned on all sides and cooked through. Remove.
In the same pan, melt more butter, whisk in flour, then slowly add stock and cream to make a gravy.
Return meatballs to the sauce and serve with mash and lingonberry jam.

data.name: Hummus with Spiced Lamb
data.introduction: While hummus is a dip, when topped with warm, spiced ground lamb and pine nuts (Hummus Kawarma), it becomes a substantial meal. This Levantine favorite combines the cool, creamy chickpea puree with the savory, hot fat of the meat.
recipe: Toast the pine nuts in a dry pan until golden; set aside.
Fry the ground lamb in olive oil until browned. Stir in the seven-spice and salt.
Deglaze the pan with pomegranate molasses and remove from heat.
Spread a thick layer of hummus on a plate, creating a well in the center.
Spoon the hot lamb into the well, garnish with pine nuts and parsley, and serve with warm pita.

data.name: Moules-Frites
data.introduction: The unofficial national dish of Belgium. This simple but elegant pairing of steamed mussels and crispy fries is a North Sea classic. The mussels are typically steamed in a broth of white wine, shallots, and parsley (Moules Marinière).
recipe: Discard any mussels that stay open when tapped.
In a large pot, melt butter and sauté shallots and garlic until translucent.
Pour in the wine and bring to a boil. Add the mussels and cover tightly.
Steam for 4–5 minutes until the shells have opened. Discard any that remain closed.
Stir in parsley and serve in large bowls with a side of hot, salty fries and mayo.

data.name: Bibimbap
data.introduction: Literally 'mixed rice.' This Korean dish is a bowl of warm white rice topped with 'namul' (seasoned vegetables), 'gochujang' (chili pepper paste), soy sauce, and a fried egg. It is a masterpiece of color, texture, and nutritional balance.
ingredients: 100g beef strips (marinated in soy and sesame)
recipe: Sauté each vegetable separately with a little sesame oil and salt to keep their colors distinct.
Fry the beef strips until cooked through.
Blanch the spinach, squeeze out water, and season with sesame oil.
Place rice in a bowl, arrange the vegetables and meat in sections on top.
Place a fried egg in the center. Serve with a dollop of gochujang and mix everything together before eating.

data.name: Piri-Piri Chicken
data.introduction: A spicy Portuguese favorite with African roots. The chicken is marinated in a fiery sauce made from Malagueta chilies, citrus, and garlic, then chargrilled to smoky perfection. It is famously associated with the Algarve region.
ingredients: 1 tsp smoked paprika and 1 tsp dried oregano
recipe: Blend chilies, garlic, oil, lemon juice, and spices to make the piri-piri sauce.
Coat the chicken in the sauce and marinate for at least 4 hours (overnight is best).
Preheat a grill or oven (200°C). Cook the chicken, skin-side up, for 35–40 minutes.
Baste with extra sauce during the last 10 minutes of cooking.
Serve with fries or a simple tomato and onion salad.

data.name: Tagine Lahm (Lamb Tagine)
data.introduction: Named after the conical clay pot it is cooked in, the Moroccan tagine is a slow-cooked stew that beautifully blends savory meat with sweet fruits like apricots or prunes. The shape of the lid traps steam and returns it to the pot, keeping the lamb incredibly moist.
recipe: Brown the lamb in the tagine or a heavy pot. Add onions and spices; cook until fragrant.
Add stock and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook on low heat for 1.5 hours.
Stir in the dried fruit and honey. Simmer for another 30 minutes until the sauce is syrupy.
Garnish with toasted almonds and fresh coriander.
Serve with couscous to soak up the aromatic sauce.

data.name: Pierogi
data.introduction: The pride of Poland. These dumplings are made by wrapping unleavened dough around a savory or sweet filling and boiling them. The 'Ruskie' version (potato and cheese) is the most popular, often served with fried onions and sour cream.
ingredients: Filling: 500g boiled potatoes (mashed), 200g Quark or Twaróg cheese
1 onion, finely diced and fried in butter
recipe: Mix the mashed potatoes, cheese, and half the fried onions to make the filling.
Knead the dough until smooth, roll thin, and cut out circles with a glass.
Place a spoonful of filling in each, fold, and pinch the edges to seal.
Boil in salted water until they float to the surface (about 3 mins).
Pan-fry in butter until slightly crispy and top with the remaining fried onions.

data.name: Fish and Chips
data.introduction: A British institution. Historically, it was a staple meal of the working class, but today it is enjoyed by everyone from beachside shacks to high-end restaurants. The secret is a light, bubbly beer batter and thick-cut 'fluffy' chips.
ingredients: 200g plain flour and 1 tsp baking powder
recipe: Whisk flour, baking powder, and cold beer until you have a smooth, thick batter.
Slice potatoes into thick chips, parboil for 5 mins, then drain and dry.
Fry the chips at 160°C until pale; remove and drain.
Dust fish in flour, dip in batter, and fry at 180°C until golden and crispy.
Re-fry the chips at the higher temperature until golden. Serve with vinegar and mushy peas.

data.name: Ceviche
data.introduction: The coastal star of Peru. This dish uses the acidity of lime juice to 'cook' fresh raw fish. It is a masterclass in freshness, balanced by the heat of ají chilies and the crunch of toasted corn (cancha). It is often served with a slice of sweet potato to cut through the citrus.
ingredients: 400g firm white fish (sea bass or sole), cubed
1 ají amarillo or habanero chili, minced
recipe: Rinse the fish in cold water and pat dry. Place in a glass bowl.
Add the lime juice, sliced onion, and chili. Ensure the fish is submerged.
Let it marinate in the fridge for 10–15 minutes (the fish will turn opaque).
Toss in the cilantro and a pinch of salt.
Serve immediately with a side of sweet potato and toasted corn.

data.name: Shashlik
data.introduction: A Central Asian and Caucasian specialty of skewered and grilled cubes of meat. Unlike many kebabs, Shashlik is traditionally marinated for a long time in an acidic base (like vinegar, pomegranate juice, or kefir) with plenty of onions, resulting in incredibly tender meat.
ingredients: 1kg lamb or pork neck, cut into large cubes
Flatbread and raw onions for serving
recipe: In a large bowl, massage the meat with salt, pepper, and the sliced onions (squeeze them to release juice).
Add the vinegar/juice, cover, and marinate for at least 4 hours (overnight is better).
Thread the meat onto large metal skewers, alternating with pieces of onion from the marinade.
Grill over hot coals for 12–15 minutes, turning frequently until charred outside and juicy inside.
Serve with flatbread and sumac-dusted onions.

data.name: Lomo Saltado
data.introduction: A perfect example of 'Chifa' (Chinese-Peruvian) fusion. This stir-fry combines strips of steak with onions, tomatoes, and—uniquely—French fries, all tossed in a soy sauce base. It is a hearty, smoky dish that bridges two continents.
recipe: Sear the steak strips in a very hot wok or pan until browned. Remove.
Sauté onions and tomatoes until the onion is soft but the tomato still holds its shape.
Add the soy sauce and vinegar, return the beef to the pan and toss.
Fold in the hot French fries and cilantro just before serving so the fries stay crisp.
Serve with white rice on the side for double the carbs!

data.name: Jamaican Patties
data.introduction: The iconic yellow-crusted handheld snack of Jamaica. The dough is tinted with turmeric or curry powder, and the filling is typically a savory, spicy ground beef mixture. It is a direct evolution of the Cornish pasty, adapted with Caribbean flavors.
recipe: Make the pastry by pulsing cold butter, flour, and turmeric. Add cold water to form a dough and chill.
Cook the beef with onions, chili, and spices. Add breadcrumbs and a splash of water to make it 'saucy'.
Roll out the dough and cut into circles.
Place filling on one half, fold, and crimp edges with a fork.
Bake at 200°C for 25 minutes until the pastry is flaky and golden.

data.name: Miso Soup
data.introduction: A fundamental pillar of Japanese dining. This soup is based on 'dashi' stock and fermented soybean paste (miso). It is prized for its 'umami' depth and probiotic benefits, typically served as a side to breakfast, lunch, or dinner.
ingredients: 500ml dashi stock (or water with dashi granules)
recipe: Bring the dashi stock to a gentle simmer. Add the wakame seaweed.
Place the miso paste in a small bowl. Ladle in a little hot stock and whisk until smooth.
Add the cubed tofu to the pot and simmer for 1 minute.
Turn off the heat and stir in the dissolved miso (boiling miso destroys its nutrients).
Top with spring onions and serve immediately.

data.name: Arepas
data.introduction: A daily bread in Venezuela and Colombia. These round, flat corn cakes are made from pre-cooked cornmeal, grilled or fried, and then split open like a pita to be stuffed with everything from cheese to 'Reina Pepiada' (chicken and avocado salad).
ingredients: Fillings: shredded cheese, black beans, or chicken
recipe: Mix water, salt, and cornmeal in a bowl. Knead until a smooth dough forms without cracks.
Form into balls and flatten into 2cm thick discs.
Heat a lightly oiled griddle. Cook the arepas for 5–7 minutes per side until a crust forms.
Finish in the oven at 180°C for 5 minutes if they need to puff up.
Slice open three-quarters of the way and stuff with your choice of filling.

data.name: Banh Mi
data.introduction: The ultimate fusion sandwich. Born in Vietnam during the French colonial period, it combines a French baguette with Vietnamese ingredients like pâté, pickled daikon/carrots, cilantro, and grilled pork. It is a perfect balance of crispy, soft, savory, and tangy.
ingredients: Cucumber strips, cilantro, and fresh chili
Mayonnaise and a dash of Maggi sauce
recipe: Lightly toast the baguette until the crust is very crispy.
Slit the bread and spread mayonnaise on one side and pâté on the other.
Layer in the meat, then the cucumber and pickles.
Top with plenty of cilantro and sliced chilies.
Add a splash of Maggi seasoning sauce and serve.

data.name: Chiles Rellenos
data.introduction: A classic Mexican comfort dish. Large Poblano chilies are roasted, stuffed with gooey cheese or meat, dipped in a fluffy egg batter, and fried until golden. They are traditionally served swimming in a light, savory tomato broth.
recipe: Roast chilies over a flame until charred. Steam in a bag for 10 mins, then peel and remove seeds.
Stuff the chilies with cheese strips and secure with a toothpick.
Beat egg whites to stiff peaks, then gently fold in the yolks and a pinch of flour.
Dredge chilies in flour, dip in the egg batter, and fry until golden on all sides.
Serve hot with tomato broth poured over the top.

data.name: Fish Amok
data.introduction: The national dish of Cambodia. This is a steamed fish curry with a mousse-like consistency. It is flavored with 'kroeung' (a complex herb paste) and coconut milk, traditionally steamed inside a banana leaf cup for an elegant presentation.
ingredients: 1 tbsp fish sauce and 1 tsp palm sugar
recipe: Whisk the kroeung paste with coconut cream, egg, fish sauce, and sugar until smooth.
Gently stir the fish slices into the mixture.
Pour the mixture into banana leaf bowls or ramekins.
Steam for 20 minutes until the curry sets into a firm, custard-like texture.
Garnish with shredded lime leaves and a drizzle of coconut cream; serve with rice.

data.name: Churros with Chocolate
data.introduction: A Spanish breakfast and snack classic. These fluted, deep-fried dough pastries are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. They are almost never eaten alone; they are the vessel for a cup of Spanish hot chocolate so thick you can practically stand a spoon in it.
ingredients: For dipping: 200g dark chocolate, 100ml cream, 1 tsp cornstarch
recipe: Boil water, butter, and sugar. Remove from heat and beat in flour until it forms a ball. Let cool slightly, then beat in the egg.
Pipe the dough through a star-tipped nozzle into hot oil (180°C).
Fry until golden and drain on paper towels. Roll in cinnamon sugar.
For the chocolate: Melt chocolate and cream together. Whisk in a little cornstarch dissolved in milk to thicken into a dipping consistency.
Serve hot and fresh.

data.name: Five-Flavor Oat Diet Cookies
data.introduction: A healthy, Stevia-sweetened treat using oat flour and flakes. This batch includes five distinct varieties: Walnut, Chocolate, Peanut Butter, Coffee, and Carrot.
ingredients: Divided additions: Crushed walnuts, Cocoa nibs, Peanut butter, Instant coffee powder, Grated carrots
recipe: Mix the oat flour, flakes, and Stevia to form a base dough.
Divide the dough into five equal portions.
Fold in the specific flavorings to each portion (walnut, chocolate, etc.).
Shape into 30 small cookies and bake at 180°C for 12-15 minutes.
Allow to cool completely to reach a crunchy texture.

data.name: Ghormeh Sabzi
data.introduction: Often called the national dish of Iran, this herb stew is a masterpiece of slow cooking. It combines sautéed herbs (parsley, cilantro, and fenugreek) with kidney beans, lamb, and sun-dried limes (limoo amani), which provide a unique, tangy depth.
ingredients: 2 cups chopped herbs (parsley, leeks, cilantro, fenugreek)
recipe: Sauté the chopped herbs in oil for about 10-15 mins until they turn dark green and fragrant.
In a separate pot, brown the onions and meat with turmeric and black pepper.
Add the beans, fried herbs, and dried limes (pierced with a fork).
Cover with water and simmer on low for 3 hours until the meat is tender and oil rises to the top.
Serve with saffron-infused basmati rice (Chelow).

data.name: Fesenjan
data.introduction: The jewel of Persian stews, Fesenjan is a decadent, sweet-and-sour dish traditionally served for celebrations. Its rich, dark sauce is made from finely ground walnuts and pomegranate molasses, usually simmered with duck or chicken.
recipe: Sauté the grated onion and brown the chicken pieces.
Add the ground walnuts and cook on low for 5 minutes, stirring to prevent burning.
Pour in cold water; the temperature change helps the walnuts release their oil.
Stir in pomegranate molasses and simmer on very low heat for 2 hours until the sauce is thick and chocolate-colored.
Adjust sweetness with sugar and serve over rice.

data.name: Tahchin
data.introduction: An elegant Persian savory rice cake. Tahchin features layers of rice flavored with saffron, yogurt, and egg yolks, sandwiched with spiced chicken and baked until it develops a crisp, golden crust known as 'Tahdig'.
recipe: Parboil the rice and drain.
Mix yogurt, egg yolks, saffron, and oil in a large bowl. Fold in the rice until yellow.
In a greased baking dish, press half the rice into the bottom. Layer with chicken and barberries.
Top with the remaining rice and press down firmly.
Cover and bake at 190°C for 75-90 minutes until the edges are deep gold. Flip onto a platter to serve.

data.name: Kabab Koobideh
data.introduction: The most popular street and restaurant food in Iran. Koobideh is made from twice-ground lamb or beef mixed with grated onions and spices, then molded onto flat skewers and grilled over hot coals.
ingredients: 2 large onions, grated and squeezed dry
1 tsp salt and 1 tsp black pepper
recipe: Mix the meat with the dry onion pulp (discard the juice to keep the meat on the skewer).
Knead the mixture for 10 minutes until it becomes sticky and paste-like.
Mold a handful of meat onto a flat metal skewer using wet hands.
Grill over very hot coals, turning every 30 seconds for about 8-10 minutes.
Serve with grilled tomatoes and sprinkle generously with sumac.

data.name: Zereshk Polo morgh
data.introduction: A vibrant and classic Persian dish consisting of saffron rice mixed with tart barberries (Zereshk) and served with a tender, tomato-based saffron chicken.
recipe: Cook the chicken with onions, turmeric, and tomato paste until tender.
Steam the basmati rice using the 'Chelow' method with a tahdig crust.
Sauté the barberries in butter and sugar for 1 minute (don't burn them).
Mix a portion of the rice with saffron water and the barberries.
Layer the bright red barberry rice over the white rice and serve with the chicken on the side.

data.name: Abgoosht (Dizi)
data.introduction: A rustic, centuries-old shepherd's stew. It is cooked in a stone or clay pot (Dizi) and consists of lamb, chickpeas, white beans, and potatoes. It is eaten in two steps: first the broth as a soup, then the solids are mashed into a paste.
recipe: Place meat, beans, onion, and turmeric in a pot with water and simmer for 3 hours.
Add potatoes, tomato paste, and dried limes. Cook for another hour.
Strain the broth into a bowl—this is the first course, eaten with pieces of flatbread (Tilit).
Mash the remaining solids (meat, beans, potatoes) into a smooth paste (Gousht Koobideh) and eat with bread and pickles.

data.name: Ash Reshteh
data.introduction: The most famous Persian thick soup. Packed with various beans, fresh herbs, and special Persian noodles (Reshteh), it is topped with fermented whey (Kashk), caramelized onions, and fried mint oil.
ingredients: 1 cup mixed beans (lentils, chickpeas, navy beans)
4 cups chopped herbs (parsley, spinach, cilantro, scallions)
Fried onions, garlic, and dried mint for garnish
recipe: Cook the beans until tender.
Add the chopped herbs and water/stock; simmer for 30 minutes.
Add the noodles (they contain salt, so adjust seasoning later). Cook until soft.
Stir in half of the Kashk.
Top with a swirl of Kashk, golden fried onions, and 'Nana Dagh' (mint sizzled in oil).

data.name: Kashk-e Bademjan
data.introduction: A savory eggplant dip that is a staple of Persian appetizers. Fried eggplants are mashed and flavored with kashk (whey), garlic, and walnuts. It is creamy, umami-rich, and incredibly satisfying.
recipe: Peel and fry eggplant slices until golden, then mash them with a fork.
Sauté garlic and onions with turmeric, then add to the eggplants.
Stir in the kashk and crushed walnuts; cook for 10 minutes on low to meld flavors.
Garnish with fried mint and extra kashk. Serve with Sangak or Lavash bread.

data.name: Sabzi Polo ba Mahi
data.introduction: The traditional meal for Nowruz (Persian New Year). It pairs aromatic herb rice (Sabzi Polo) with fried or smoked fish, usually whitefish from the Caspian Sea.
ingredients: 2 cups chopped herbs (parsley, cilantro, dill, fenugreek)
recipe: Parboil rice and drain. Layer the rice with the fresh chopped herbs in a pot.
Steam until a golden tahdig forms at the bottom.
Marinate fish in lemon, saffron, and salt, then pan-fry until crispy.
Serve the herb-rich rice with the fish and fresh Seville orange (Narenj).

data.name: Joojeh Kabab
data.introduction: Grilled chicken skewers marinated in a vibrant mixture of saffron, lemon juice, and onions. The saffron gives the chicken a beautiful golden color and an unmistakable aroma.
ingredients: 1kg chicken (bone-in or breast), cut into pieces
recipe: Marinate chicken in lemon, saffron, onions, and salt for at least 4 hours.
Thread chicken onto skewers.
Grill over coals, basting with melted butter and saffron during the final minutes.
Serve with saffron rice or wrapped in hot flatbread.
